title: Apostle Paul Quiz - Multi-Level
description: Test your knowledge about the Apostle Paul — from his conversion on the Damascus Road to his missionary journeys, epistles, and imprisonment for the Gospel.

easy.title: Apostle Paul Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Apostle Paul in the Bible.

questions.question: Before his conversion, what was Saul's attitude toward Christians?
questions.explanation: Acts 8:3 shows that Saul was actively persecuting the church by going from house to house to arrest Christians.

questions.question: Where was Saul traveling when he experienced his dramatic conversion?
questions.explanation: Acts 9:3-6 describes Saul's encounter with Jesus on the road to Damascus, leading to his conversion.

questions.question: In which city did Paul and Barnabas begin their first missionary journey?
questions.explanation: Acts 13:1-3 shows that Paul and Barnabas were sent out from the church in Antioch for their first missionary journey.

questions.question: What was the main issue discussed at the Jerusalem Council where Paul was present?
options: Whether to build a new temple
Whether to collect offerings for the poor
Whether to stop preaching to Gentiles
questions.explanation: Acts 15:5-11 records the debate about circumcision for Gentile believers, a key topic at the Jerusalem Council.

questions.question: During which missionary journey did Paul spend 18 months teaching in Corinth?
questions.explanation: Acts 18:11 states that Paul stayed in Corinth for a year and a half during his second missionary journey.

questions.question: True or False: Paul was arrested in Jerusalem and later taken to Caesarea for trials.
questions.explanation: Acts 21:27-36 and Acts 23:23-35 show Paul was arrested in Jerusalem and transferred to Caesarea for trial.

questions.question: Who was the Roman governor before whom Paul first gave his defense in Caesarea?
questions.explanation: Acts 24:24-25 shows Paul giving his defense before Governor Felix.

questions.question: What happened to Paul during his voyage to Rome that is recorded in Acts?
options: He was welcomed warmly in Rome
questions.explanation: Acts 27:39-44 and 28:1 describe Paul's shipwreck on the island of Malta during his journey to Rome.

questions.question: What key doctrine did Paul emphasize in Romans regarding how people are made right with God?
questions.explanation: Romans 3:28 highlights that a person is justified by faith apart from works of the law.

questions.question: True or False: Paul described the church as the 'body of Christ' in his letters.
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 12:27 states that believers collectively form the body of Christ.

questions.question: Which letter of Paul contains instructions about spiritual gifts and their proper use in the church?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians chapters 12-14 discuss spiritual gifts and their use in the church.

questions.question: What did Paul say about the resurrection of the dead in 1 Corinthians 15?
options: Christ's resurrection guarantees believers will also be raised
questions.correctAnswer: Christ's resurrection guarantees believers will also be raised
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:20-22 teaches that Christ's resurrection is the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep, promising resurrection for believers.

questions.question: Paul refers to a 'thorn in the flesh' given to him. What was its purpose according to him?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:7 explains Paul’s thorn was given to keep him from becoming conceited.

questions.question: True or False: Paul was imprisoned in Rome and was allowed to receive visitors while under house arrest.
questions.explanation: Acts 28:30-31 states Paul was under house arrest in Rome but welcomed all who came to him.

questions.question: Paul was known as the Apostle to the ______.
questions.explanation: Romans 11:13 refers to Paul as the apostle to the Gentiles, highlighting his mission focus.

medium.title: Apostle Paul Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Apply biblical truths from Apostle Paul's life to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with bitterness after facing persecution. Based on Apostle Paul's experience as Saul persecuted Christians, what biblical truth would you share about forgiveness and transformation?
options: God can transform even the hardest hearts through His mercy and grace.
Persecution is a sign that God has abandoned His people.
Only those born into faith can be changed by God.
Forgiveness is unnecessary if the offense is severe.
questions.correctAnswer: God can transform even the hardest hearts through His mercy and grace.
questions.explanation: Acts 7:58-8:3 shows Saul persecuting Christians, yet God transformed him (Acts 9:1-19). This teaches that no one is beyond God's grace. Paul's transformation into an apostle exemplifies forgiveness and renewal (1 Timothy 1:12-16; 2 Corinthians 5:17).

questions.question: How does Apostle Paul's Damascus road conversion teach us about trusting God's call even when it disrupts plans?
options: Obedient faith requires surrendering personal plans to God's mission.
God only calls those who are already perfect and ready.
Doubt is a sign that God is not calling you.
God's call is always easy and without hardship.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedient faith requires surrendering personal plans to God's mission.
questions.explanation: Paul’s sudden conversion (Acts 9:3-18) interrupted his persecution of Christians and called him to spread the Gospel. His obedience despite uncertainty (Philippians 3:7-14; Galatians 1:15-16) encourages believers to trust God’s plan above their own.

questions.question: A new church leader struggles with balancing teaching and pastoral care. Based on Paul's ministry in Antioch, what principle would you share about leadership in the church?
options: Effective ministry combines solid teaching with nurturing community.
Leadership is mainly about enforcing rules strictly.
Popularity is the most important quality in leadership.
Leaders should avoid difficult conversations to keep peace.
questions.correctAnswer: Effective ministry combines solid teaching with nurturing community.
questions.explanation: Acts 11:25-26 describes Paul and Barnabas teaching and strengthening disciples in Antioch. Paul’s letters (Ephesians 4:11-13; 1 Timothy 3:1-7) emphasize teaching, shepherding, and building unity for healthy churches.

questions.question: How does Paul's first missionary journey teach us about perseverance in sharing the Gospel despite opposition?
options: Faithfulness includes enduring trials and opposition for Christ.
If ministry faces hardship, it should be abandoned.
Success is measured by immediate acceptance.
Avoid difficult places to prevent conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness includes enduring trials and opposition for Christ.
questions.explanation: During the first missionary journey (Acts 13-14), Paul faced persecution (Acts 14:19-22) but encouraged perseverance. His example teaches believers to remain steadfast, trusting God’s purpose (Romans 5:3-5; 2 Timothy 4:5).

questions.question: Based on the Jerusalem Council, how does Paul's example teach us about unity and resolving doctrinal disputes in the church?
options: Seek unity through open dialogue and reliance on Scripture and the Holy Spirit.
Impose beliefs without discussion to maintain order.
Avoid addressing disagreements to prevent division.
Accept all opinions as equally valid regardless of Scripture.
questions.correctAnswer: Seek unity through open dialogue and reliance on Scripture and the Holy Spirit.
questions.explanation: Acts 15 records the Jerusalem Council where Paul and others discussed Gentile believers’ requirements. The decision (Acts 15:28-29) shows the importance of listening, Scripture, and Spirit-led consensus for unity (Ephesians 4:1-6; Philippians 2:1-4).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged after facing repeated setbacks in ministry. How does Paul's second and third missionary journeys teach about perseverance and reliance on God's strength?
options: Perseverance through hardships is empowered by God's grace and purpose.
Setbacks indicate failure and should end ministry efforts.
Success depends solely on human effort, not on God.
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance through hardships is empowered by God's grace and purpose.
questions.explanation: Paul’s journeys (Acts 16-20) included imprisonments, beatings, and opposition (2 Corinthians 11:23-28) but he remained faithful, relying on God’s strength (Philippians 4:13; 2 Timothy 2:3-6). This models perseverance amid trials.

questions.question: How does Paul's arrest in Jerusalem demonstrate the importance of respectful witness even when falsely accused?
options: Maintaining respect and clear testimony honors God under persecution.
Defend yourself aggressively to win arguments.
Avoid speaking when accused to stay safe.
Retaliate against false accusations to protect reputation.
questions.correctAnswer: Maintaining respect and clear testimony honors God under persecution.
questions.explanation: In Acts 21-22, Paul was arrested unjustly but gave a respectful defense of his faith before the crowd and authorities (Acts 22:1-21). His conduct (1 Peter 2:12; 1 Timothy 1:16) teaches believers to witness calmly under trial.

questions.question: How does Paul's trial before Felix, Festus, and Agrippa teach about courage and trust in God's sovereignty during difficult times?
options: Trusting God’s plan enables boldness even amid uncertainty.
Fear should prevent you from speaking your faith.
Only speak when conditions are perfectly safe.
Avoid legal authorities to prevent trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God’s plan enables boldness even amid uncertainty.
questions.explanation: Paul’s trials before Felix, Festus, and Agrippa (Acts 24-26) show his fearless testimony despite imprisonment. He trusted God’s sovereignty (Romans 8:28; Philippians 1:12-14) and courageously shared the Gospel.

questions.question: A believer is feeling weak and discouraged because of ongoing struggles. Based on Paul's 'thorn in the flesh,' what biblical truth would you share?
options: God’s grace is sufficient, and His power is made perfect in weakness.
Struggles mean God has abandoned you.
You must overcome weaknesses on your own strength.
Weakness is a sign of spiritual failure.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s grace is sufficient, and His power is made perfect in weakness.
questions.explanation: Paul describes his thorn in the flesh in 2 Corinthians 12:7-10, explaining that God’s grace sustains him and strength is shown in weakness. This encourages believers to rely on God's power, not their own.

questions.question: How does Paul's shipwreck on Malta teach us about trusting God's providence during unexpected trials?
options: God’s protection and purpose remain even in life’s storms.
Danger means God has forsaken you.
Avoid risks to prevent all troubles.
Self-reliance is the best way to survive crises.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s protection and purpose remain even in life’s storms.
questions.explanation: Acts 27-28 recount Paul’s shipwreck but God preserved all aboard, fulfilling His purpose for Paul’s ministry. This shows God’s providential care amid hardship (Psalm 91:1-4; Romans 8:38-39).

questions.question: How does Paul's imprisonment in Rome illustrate the importance of rejoicing and prayer in difficult circumstances?
options: Rejoicing and prayer sustain believers even in hardship.
Despair is the only appropriate response to suffering.
questions.correctAnswer: Rejoicing and prayer sustain believers even in hardship.
questions.explanation: While imprisoned in Rome, Paul encouraged believers to rejoice and pray continually (Philippians 4:4-7; Ephesians 6:18). His example teaches maintaining joy and spiritual discipline despite suffering (Colossians 4:2).

questions.question: A believer is confused about how justification before God is achieved. Based on Paul's teaching, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Justification is by faith in Jesus Christ, not by works of the law.
Good works alone justify a person before God.
Faith and works have equal roles in justification.
Justification depends on following religious rituals.
questions.correctAnswer: Justification is by faith in Jesus Christ, not by works of the law.
questions.explanation: Paul clearly teaches justification by faith in Romans 3:28, 5:1 and Galatians 2:16, emphasizing trust in Christ’s work rather than law-keeping. This is foundational to Christian assurance and grace (Ephesians 2:8-9).

questions.question: How does Paul's teaching on the 'body of Christ' in 1 Corinthians help us understand unity and diversity in the church?
options: Each member has unique gifts and is vital to the whole body.
Only a few gifted leaders matter in the church.
Uniformity in all roles is required for unity.
questions.correctAnswer: Each member has unique gifts and is vital to the whole body.
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 12:12-27, Paul explains the church as a body with many parts, each necessary. This teaches the value of diverse gifts working together in unity (Ephesians 4:16; Romans 12:4-8).

questions.question: True or False: Apostle Paul taught that the resurrection of Jesus is central to Christian hope and faith.
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes the resurrection as essential to faith in 1 Corinthians 15:12-22 and Romans 6:4-5, stating that without it, Christian hope is in vain.

questions.question: True or False: Paul instructed Timothy to avoid teaching sound doctrine to prevent offending others.
questions.explanation: Paul urges Timothy to preach sound doctrine boldly (2 Timothy 4:2-4) despite opposition, emphasizing faithfulness over popularity (1 Timothy 4:13-16).

hard.title: Apostle Paul Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections about Apostle Paul.

questions.question: Before his conversion, what was Saul's primary activity regarding early Christians?
questions.explanation: Acts 8:3 describes Saul as ravaging the church and entering houses to drag off men and women, showing his active persecution of Christians.

questions.question: During Saul's encounter on the Damascus road, what question did Jesus ask him?
options: "Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?"
"Do you believe in the Son of Man?"
questions.correctAnswer: "Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?"
questions.explanation: In Acts 9:4, Jesus addresses Saul with this question, revealing the identification of the church with Christ himself.

questions.question: Where did Barnabas first bring Saul to join the Christian community after his conversion?
questions.explanation: Acts 11:25-26 narrates Barnabas bringing Saul to Antioch where they taught the church for a whole year, marking the beginning of Saul's wider ministry.

questions.question: Which city was NOT visited during Paul's first missionary journey?
questions.explanation: Acts 13-14 records the first missionary journey including Iconium, Lystra, and Derbe, but Ephesus is visited later on the second journey (Acts 18:19).

questions.question: What was the main issue debated at the Jerusalem Council involving Paul and the apostles?
options: Whether Gentile believers must be circumcised
Whether Christians should observe Jewish dietary laws
Whether to include women in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Whether Gentile believers must be circumcised
questions.explanation: Acts 15:1-29 describes the council debating if Gentile converts must follow Mosaic law, especially circumcision, affirming salvation by grace.

questions.question: During Paul's second missionary journey, which city did he visit where he met a woman named Lydia?
questions.explanation: Acts 16:14 introduces Lydia, a seller of purple goods in Philippi, who becomes one of the first European converts.

questions.question: What key doctrine does Paul emphasize in Romans 3:28?
options: Justification by faith apart from works of the law
The unity of Jew and Gentile in Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Justification by faith apart from works of the law
questions.explanation: Romans 3:28 states that a person is justified by faith apart from the works of the law, a central Pauline doctrine.

questions.question: Paul uses the metaphor of the 'body' to describe the church in which letter?
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 12:12-27, Paul explains the church as one body with many members, emphasizing unity and diversity.

questions.question: What was Paul's 'thorn in the flesh' as described in 2 Corinthians 12:7?
questions.explanation: Paul mentions a 'thorn in the flesh' given to keep him from pride, commonly interpreted as a physical weakness or ailment (2 Corinthians 12:7).

questions.question: True or False: Paul was shipwrecked on the island of Malta during his journey to Rome as a prisoner.
questions.explanation: Acts 27:39-44 and 28:1 record Paul's shipwreck on Malta while being transported to Rome.

questions.question: Before which Roman governor did Paul first make his defense after his arrest in Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: Acts 24:24-27 describes Paul's appearance before Felix where he defends his faith and is kept in custody.

questions.question: In Paul's letter to Philemon, what relationship does he emphasize between Philemon and Onesimus?
questions.explanation: Philemon 1:16 urges Philemon to receive Onesimus no longer as a slave but as a beloved brother in Christ.

questions.question: Which epistle contains Paul's teaching about the resurrection of the dead as central to Christian faith?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15 extensively discusses the resurrection of the dead, affirming its essential place in the gospel.

questions.question: In which city did Paul spend 18 months teaching, leading to a strong and influential church, during his second missionary journey?
questions.explanation: Acts 18:11 notes Paul stayed in Corinth for a year and a half, establishing the church there.

questions.question: Paul describes the gift of speaking in tongues as one of many spiritual gifts in which letter?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 12 and 14 discuss spiritual gifts including speaking in tongues and their proper use in the church.

theological.title: Apostle Paul Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology exploring Apostle Paul's significance in God's redemptive plan.

questions.question: Before his conversion, how did Saul (later Paul) persecute the early Christians?
options: He approved the stoning of Stephen
questions.correctAnswer: He approved the stoning of Stephen
questions.explanation: Acts 7:58-8:1 shows Saul approving Stephen's stoning, highlighting his initial role in persecuting Christians, consistent with his zeal against the church as seen in Acts 9:1-2; Philippians 3:6; Galatians 1:13; and 1 Timothy 1:13.

questions.question: What key event led to Saul’s conversion and transformation into Paul?
options: A vision of Jesus on the road to Damascus
A dream of the risen Christ in Antioch
questions.correctAnswer: A vision of Jesus on the road to Damascus
questions.explanation: Acts 9:3-6 recounts Saul's encounter with the risen Christ on the Damascus road, which marks his conversion. This event reveals Christ's lordship (1 Timothy 1:15), the power to save sinners (Titus 3:5), and fulfills Old Testament prophecy of God's salvation (Isaiah 53:5; Jeremiah 31:34; Joel 2:28).

questions.question: Where was Paul first significantly involved in ministry alongside Barnabas after his conversion?
questions.explanation: Acts 11:25-26 describes Paul and Barnabas teaching in Antioch, where disciples were first called Christians. This ministry hub reflects the church's expansion (Acts 13:1-3), unity in mission (Romans 15:26), and the fulfillment of the Abrahamic blessing (Genesis 12:3).

questions.question: During Paul’s first missionary journey, which island did he and Barnabas primarily evangelize?
questions.explanation: Acts 13:4-12 details the journey to Cyprus, where Paul confronted a sorcerer Elymas, demonstrating the gospel's triumph over falsehood, consistent with God's sovereignty in salvation (Isaiah 42:6-7; Psalm 2:8; Jeremiah 1:5; Matthew 28:19-20).

questions.question: What was the main issue addressed at the Jerusalem Council involving Paul and the apostles?
options: Whether Gentile believers must be circumcised
The role of women in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Whether Gentile believers must be circumcised
questions.explanation: Acts 15:1-29 recounts the Jerusalem Council debating circumcision for Gentiles, affirming salvation by grace through faith apart from works of the law (Galatians 2:16; Romans 3:28; Ephesians 2:8-9; Philippians 3:3).

questions.question: Which city was a major center for Paul’s second missionary journey where he established a strong church?
questions.explanation: Acts 18:1-11 shows Paul’s extended ministry in Corinth, emphasizing justification by faith (Romans 5:1), unity in the body of Christ (1 Corinthians 12:12-27), and resurrection hope (1 Corinthians 15:20-22), aligning with God's covenant promises (Genesis 12:1-3).

questions.question: What was a key doctrinal theme Paul taught in Ephesians regarding the church?
options: The church as the body of Christ
The exclusive role of Jewish believers
questions.correctAnswer: The church as the body of Christ
questions.explanation: Ephesians 1:22-23 presents the church as Christ's body, revealing the mystery of God's plan to unite Jews and Gentiles (Ephesians 2:14-16), fulfilling Old Testament promises (Isaiah 11:10; Ezekiel 37:24-28; Psalm 22:27).

questions.question: Which Apostle Paul metaphorically described his struggle with a 'thorn in the flesh'?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 12:7-9 refers to Paul's 'thorn in the flesh,' likely a physical affliction, illustrating God's power in weakness (Isaiah 40:29; Psalm 73:26; John 9:1-3; Romans 8:28), emphasizing grace over human strength.

questions.question: During Paul’s arrest and trials, before which Roman governor did he first give his defense?
questions.explanation: Acts 24:24-27 shows Paul’s defense before Felix, highlighting his witness to the resurrection and righteousness, affirming Christ’s lordship (Acts 23:6; Romans 1:4; 1 Corinthians 15:3-4; Philippians 2:9-11).

questions.question: What happened to Paul during his voyage to Rome that demonstrated God’s providence?
options: He was welcomed by Caesar immediately
He escaped through a secret tunnel
questions.explanation: Acts 27:39-44 and 28:1 describe the shipwreck on Malta, showing God’s protection and purpose despite suffering (Psalm 107:23-30; Jonah 1:17; Isaiah 43:2; Romans 8:28; 2 Corinthians 4:8-9).

questions.question: Which letter of Paul most clearly articulates justification by faith apart from works of the law?
questions.explanation: Romans 3:28 and 5:1 emphasize justification by faith alone, echoing Old Testament themes of righteousness credited by faith (Genesis 15:6; Habakkuk 2:4; Isaiah 53:11; Galatians 2:16), foundational for Christian doctrine.

questions.question: In which letter does Paul discuss spiritual gifts and their purpose for the edification of the church?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 12:4-31 explains spiritual gifts as given by the Spirit for building up the body of Christ, reflecting Old Testament gifting (Exodus 31:3; Numbers 11:25; Joel 2:28) and New Testament unity (Ephesians 4:11-13).

questions.question: What is the primary hope Paul emphasizes concerning resurrection in his letters?
options: Believers will be raised imperishable like Christ
Only the soul lives on after death
The body remains in the grave forever
questions.correctAnswer: Believers will be raised imperishable like Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 15:42-44 teaches resurrection bodies will be imperishable and glorified like Christ’s, affirming the doctrine of bodily resurrection (Daniel 12:2; Job 19:25-27; Isaiah 26:19; John 11:25).

questions.question: Which letter of Paul was written to encourage a young pastor to remain faithful despite opposition and false teaching?
questions.explanation: 2 Timothy 1:6-14 exhorts Timothy to persevere in sound doctrine amid hardship, mirroring Old Testament encouragement to faithful leaders (Joshua 1:9; Psalm 27:14; Isaiah 40:31; Jeremiah 1:17).

questions.question: How does Paul describe the relationship between law and grace in Galatians?
options: The law was a tutor until Christ came
The law is the means of salvation
Grace is unnecessary if the law is kept
The law and grace are identical
questions.correctAnswer: The law was a tutor until Christ came
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:24-25 calls the law a guardian until Christ, pointing to salvation by grace through faith (Exodus 19:6; Deuteronomy 6:5; Isaiah 61:1-3; Romans 6:14), demonstrating the new covenant fulfillment.
